annotation.TEXT: On the other hand, the Killer Plant viruses are great for chip farming. There's two variants here that drop the Tree Bomb 1 and 2 chips, both of which are great throwing weapons. They don't deal multiple hits like the bomb chips do, but they make up for this by having big damage output.

Fun fact: The Gabyoalls in this game can actually drop battle chips as well. These first variants drop Stone Body, which you might recognize as a chip from the starting folder. As a word of advice: don't bother using it. While Stone Body may grant you invincibility, you're completely restricted from moving or attacking while it's active.
Way ahead of you there, pops. >_>
Quick, there's no time! Exciting email reading action, go!

Since I eventually ended up grinding for zenny, I figured I may as well stop by NumberMan in the process. Aside from selling the usual status upgrades, his inventory also includes some new chips now (mainly the Tornado-series; Good for minor enemies since it deals multiple hits, but not so much when it comes to bosses).

With that out of the way, it's time to...completely ignore the story and do a few other things first - such as beating up GutsMan.EXE again. Aside from his Navi chip, GutsMan can drop the "Gut Punch" chip. While it has strong damage output, it's not really worth using since it eventually gets eclipsed by the Silver/Gold Fist chips later on (which not only deal more damage, but also have an added piercing attribute).

If there's one thing I've learned from this area: Never waste your time with the Popper viruses (the pine cone-looking enemies). They can only be damaged if you hit them in the head...and believe me: unless you have bomb chips and a good angle to work off of, this is much more annoying than it sounds.

Compared to the first two bosses, NeedleMan.EXE is downright easy. His attacks are a bit more well-telegraphed, though he can still catch you off-guard at times (his Needle Cannon is pretty fast, and if you get too close to him, he'll try to skewer you with the needles on his body). Apparently however, the easier the boss, the more likely it is for me to mess things up. If anything, I'll take this fight as a sign to buy more Memory upgrades from NumberMan.

Before I move on with the story, there's one last thing I want to pick up. Since I'm going through these next sections in order (as in, the order of the emails), the Wood Armor is going to be very helpful for the first of these areas. While it's not absolutely necessary that you get the elemental armors from Higsby's shop, they still tone down the overall amount of damage from a majority of enemies in certain areas.

And then we have the Mushy viruses. These things drop Spice chips, which summons a bunch of moving projectiles around you. While it has decent damage output, it's not really worth using in my opinion (you need to stand pretty close to hit something with it - and if you get the idea to use it as a pseudo-shield of sorts, you're just going to end up getting hurt).

Speaking of the fist-series chips, it's time to put the Bronze Fist to use. Who remembers that suspicious looking wall back in Den Area 2? In order to break through it, you need to have a chip that has piercing attributes (which Bronze Fist happens to have). Something else you'll need for this is an Unlocker sub-chip, which can be bought at Higsby's for 1,500 zenny (the process of buying it was something I forgot to show on-screen, but either way, you still need it to actually get the contents of the Mystery Data).
<-- Dick Move (This Mettaur only falls when you jump up here)
